Summary Paul N. Stockton is Managing Director of Sonecon, LLC. 
 
Before joining Sonecon, Dr. Stockton served as the Assistant Secretary of Defense for Homeland Defense and Americas’ Security Affairs from June, 2009 until January, 2013. In that position, helped lead the Department’s response to Superstorm Sandy and other disasters, guided Defense Critical Infrastructure Protection, and oversaw DOD continuity of operations programs and policies. Dr. Stockton was also responsible for DOD initiatives to strengthen security in the Western Hemisphere. In September, 2013, Secretary of Defense Chuck Hagel appointed Dr. Stockton to co-chair the Independent Review of the Washington Navy Yard Shootings, which recommended major changes to the Department’s security clearance system that are now being implemented.  
 
Prior to his tenure as Assistant Secretary, Dr. Stockton served as Senior Research Scholar at Stanford University’s Center for International Security and Cooperation, Associate Provost of the Naval Postgraduate School, and Legislative Assistant for foreign and defense policy for Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan. 
 
Dr. Stockton holds a Ph.D. from Harvard University and a BA from Dartmouth College. His recent publications include articles on cyber security in the Yale Law and Policy Review, Stanford Law and Policy Review and other journals. Dr. Stockton was twice awarded the Department of Defense Medal for Distinguished Public Service, DOD’s highest civilian award. In addition, the Department of Homeland Security awarded Dr. Stockton its Distinguished Public Service Medal. Summary Paul N. Stockton is Managing Director of Sonecon, LLC.

Experience Managing Director Sonecon LLC January 2013  – Present (2 years 8 months) Washington, DC Sonecon is an advisory firm that analyzes risks to the operations and investment strategies of large organizations and advises their executives on how to meet these challenges. The firm helps clients build resilience against emerging threats to their infrastructure and continuity of operations, and conduct effective crisis management and communications. Also provides rigorous analysis of opportunities and potential risks for corporations weighing major foreign direct investment in South America, Central America and the Caribbean. Each Sonecon client receives the personal attention and analysis of a custom team of experts assembled from the United States and across the Western Hemisphere. Assistant Secretary of Defense for Homeland Defense and Americas' Security Affairs United States Department of Defense May 2009  –  January 2013  (3 years 9 months) Responsible for Department of Defense initiatives to strengthen security in the Western Hemisphere and help partner nations build their capacities to meet emerging security challenges. Created the Department’s first-ever Mission Assurance Strategy, and launched a range of initiatives with the private sector, the Department of Energy, and the Department of Homeland Security to help ensure the availability of energy to DoD facilities. Guided the Defense Critical Infrastructure Protection program, served as DoD's Domestic Crisis Manager, and helped lead the Department's response to Superstorm Sandy, Deepwater Horizon and other disasters. In addition, was responsible for DoD policy on continuity of operations, domestic antiterrorism, maritime domain awareness, air sovereignty and preparedness for chemical, biological, radiological and nuclear events. Summary Academic Degrees: 
 
Bsc Hons Molecular Biology. Ph.D. in Pathology 
 
 
Experience/positions 
 
Current: 
 
UCSF 2010-current 
 
Investigating/leading a novel projects to reverse adverse affects of Myocardial Infarct at the UCSF translational cardiac stem cell research program. 
 
 
Past: 
 
Weatherall Institute of Molecular Medicine, Cancer Research UK, Oxford 1998-2003: 
 
Discovered a new pathway of cellular oxygen sensing while at Weatherall Institute of Molecular Medicine, cancer Research UK, Oxford and University of Sheffield, UK.  
 
 
Stanford University 2005-2010: 
 
Discovered additional new pathways of cellular oxygen sensing at Stanford University; Received the Stanford University Dean's Award; Demonstrated that the oxygen sensing pathways are altered in circulating tumor cells. 
 
 
 
General:  
 
An avid martial artist for the past 25 years; registered black belt at Kukkiwon, Seoul Korea; still very active.  
 
An avid horseman. enjoy bareback riding; looking forward to take part in a major endurance race. 
 
Other interests include acting and film industry. 
 
Specialties:  
-Myocardial Infarct Microenvironment 
-Bio-medical technology 
-Cancer associated signaling pathways 
-Molecular and cellular oxygen sensing/signaling pathways  
-Anoxia and ischemia pathways relevant to anti-angiogenesis therapies in cancer  
-Writing, editing, presentation  
-Communication, negotiation Summary Academic Degrees:

Summary Research and outreach on Japanese security policy, encompassing both defense and diplomacy. I hope to help foster understanding of Japanese policies and promote appropriate responses to ease the integration of Japan as a dynamic agent of regional and global peace. Summary My work examines "sex testing"​ policies for elite female athletes on ceiling on the amount of natural testosterone women can have (Olympic, IAAF, FIFA, etc.). My research on these policies has been published in Science, BMJ, and the American Journal of Bioethics, with commentaries in the New York Times, The Guardian, New Scientist, and Discover. 
 
I helped to mount Dutee Chand’s successful appeal against the IAAF’s hyperandrogenism regulation at the Court of Arbitration for Sport (Lausanne, Switzerland), and served as an expert witness in the hearing. I began my career looking at controversies over treatment for people with intersex traits, which resulted in my book Fixing Sex: Intersex, Medical Authority, and Lived Experience (Duke 2008).  
 
My work has been covered in the New York Times, Time, BuzzFeed, The Week, CNN, ESPN, The Daily Beast, The Los Angeles Times, Boston Globe, Jezebel, Slate, The Advocate, La Liberation, The Chronicle of Higher Education, San Jose Mercury News, and the Toronto Star. I’ve also appeared on The World, BBC, CBS News, NBC News, KCBS, CTV News, Q Radio, Al Jazeera, and the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, among others. 
 
I am an anthropologist and bioethicist at the Center for Biomedical Ethics at Stanford University and a faculty affiliate in the Program for Feminist, Gender, and Sexuality Studies, also at Stanford. 
 
You can see more about my work here http://www.katrinakarkazis.com Summary My work examines "sex testing"​ policies for elite female athletes on ceiling on the amount of natural testosterone women can have (Olympic, IAAF, FIFA, etc.). Summary Research and Clinical Psychologist specializing in the assessment of emotional expression and its impact on business relationships, as well as psychological and physical health. Specialties:Assessing emotional expression in business relationships to impact hiring decisions, and increase effective communication. Focus on communication, emotional expression, and cancer survivorship Founder, President and CEO iEMPATH, LLC October 2007  – Present (7 years 11 months) Scientific assessment of emotional expression in business relationships. Based on our assessment, we have predicted  
 
-The productivity and efficiency of teams 
-The success of salespeople; and 
-Effectiveness in hiring 
 
We also provide expert training to increase effective communication. Summary Nationally and internationally recognized energy expert with over 35 years' experience. Expertise covers energy efficiency, demand response, smart grid, renewable energy resources, transmission, and climate change. Extensive experience in all facets of energy policy and regulation, utilities, market development and innovation, and key factors driving U.S. and global energy investments. Experience Senior Research Scholar Stanford University May 2014  – Present (1 year 4 months) Stanford, CA In May 2014, appointed with Stanford University as a Senior Research Scholar with the Precourt Energy Efficiency Center and the Shultz-Stephenson Energy Policy Task Force, to spearhead an increased focus of Stanford on state and regional energy issues, focusing in particular on regulatory policy governance and the next generation of energy efficiency. Founder and Principal Dian Grueneich Consulting, LLC March 2012  – Present (3 years 6 months) Assists clients on a full range of energy issues, focusing on U.S. and worldwide energy markets and the regulatory systems affecting sustainable energy investments. Partner Morrison & Foerster LLP March 2011  –  March 2012  (1 year 1 month) Advised clients on energy regulation, policy, and market opportunities, both in the U.S. and internationally. Represented clients in regulatory and transactional matters, and assisted in strategic business analysis. Commissioner California Public Utilities Commission 2005  –  2010  (5 years) Appointed in 2005 by Governor Schwarzenegger and confirmed unanimously by the California Senate. Lead Commissioner for: 
- Energy efficiency, including long-range market transformation 
- Demand response 
- Advanced metering infrastructure cases for 3 major CA utilities 
- Transmission planning and permitting 
- Western U.S. energy matters 
- Representation of CA Climate Action Plan Team 
- Low income energy issues Founder and Principal Grueneich Resource Advocates (GRA) 1985  –  2004  (19 years) San Francisco Bay Area Developed strategic energy plans for the County of Los Angeles and for the California State University.
